_description: UK Political Structure post-July 2024 General Election. Research for Chancellor simulation game.
_source: Electoral Commission results, parliamentary records, polling data, political analysis. As of July 2024.

electionResults2024._turnoutNote: Lowest since 2001. Suggests lack of enthusiasm rather than positive mandate for Labour.
electionResults2024._majorityNote: Massive seat majority but built on just 33.7% vote share -- the lowest vote share for a majority government in modern UK history. The majority is 'wide but shallow'.

keySwingData.reformImpact: Reform UK split the right-wing vote, costing Conservatives an estimated 50-80 seats
keySwingData._note: Many Labour seats won with <40% vote share due to Reform splitting the right. These seats are vulnerable in a two-party contest.

labourFactions._description: Internal Labour party factions the player-Chancellor must navigate

starmeriteCentre.description: Core Starmer loyalists. Pragmatic, centrist, fiscally cautious.
starmeriteCentre.rebellionTriggers: Unlikely to rebel against leadership. Would only break ranks if policy dramatically shifted leftward.
starmeriteCentre._note: This is the governing faction. Their preferences drive baseline policy.

softLeft.description: Centre-left. Loyal to Labour but with social democratic instincts stronger than Starmer's.
policyPriorities: Workers' rights (New Deal for Working People)
rebellionTriggers: Any move toward NHS privatisation or PFI-style deals
Welfare cuts that increase child poverty
Failure to implement workers' rights pledges
Excessive fiscal austerity that cuts public services
softLeft.rebellionThreshold: Would abstain before voting against. 15-30 abstentions on key votes.

socialistCampaignGroup.description: Hard left. Corbyn-era survivors. Many were deselected or chose not to stand.
policyPriorities: Public ownership of utilities and rail
Wealth tax and much higher taxes on the rich
rebellionTriggers: Any fiscal consolidation that cuts welfare
Private sector involvement in public services
socialistCampaignGroup.rebellionThreshold: Will vote against regularly. Too small to defeat government alone.

tradeUnionWing.description: MPs with strong union ties. Overlap with soft left.
rebellionTriggers: Public sector pay freeze or below-inflation settlement
Outsourcing or privatisation of public services

strikeCalibration._note: Under a Labour government, unions are more reluctant to strike but will if provoked. The 'embarrassment threshold' is higher but not infinite.
strikeCalibration._interpretation: Strike probability is roughly halved under a Labour government vs Conservative, but returns to normal if pay cuts persist beyond 18 months

blueLabour.description: Socially conservative Labour MPs from post-industrial seats. Pro-worker but culturally traditional.
rebellionTriggers: Immigration policy perceived as too liberal
Industrial areas losing out to London investment

newLabourRevivalists.description: Blairite modernisers. Pro-market, pro-EU alignment (informally), pro-reform.
policyPriorities: NHS reform and efficiency (not just more money)

starmerReeves.relationship: Professional and respectful but not close personal allies
strengths: Both share fiscal caution and centrist instincts
Reeves has genuine economics expertise (Bank of England background)
Starmer delegates fiscal policy to Reeves more than Blair did to Brown
United on key messaging: growth, fiscal responsibility, 'no return to austerity'
tensions: Reeves is more fiscally conservative than some of Starmer's political instincts
Spending departments lobby Starmer directly to override Treasury resistance
Reeves's fiscal rules constrain Starmer's desire to show visible change quickly
Immigration: Home Office/Treasury tension on asylum costs
starmerReeves.powerBalance: Treasury is dominant in fiscal matters but less dominant than under Brown. No. 10 retains more control over political strategy.

historicalPrecedents.dynamic: Rivalry and parallel power centres. Brown controlled fiscal policy almost entirely. Resulted in strong fiscal discipline but also spending splurge in 2000s.
historicalPrecedents.lesson: A dominant Chancellor can maintain fiscal discipline but at cost of political tension.

historicalPrecedents.dynamic: PM dominated but respected Darling's expertise during financial crisis. Darling was more cautious than Brown wanted.
historicalPrecedents.lesson: PM-Chancellor alignment under crisis is essential.

historicalPrecedents.dynamic: Very close allies. Osborne was 'co-PM'. Austerity was joint political project.
historicalPrecedents.lesson: Alignment enables dramatic fiscal action but creates groupthink risk.

historicalPrecedents.dynamic: Tension. Hammond wanted pragmatic Brexit; May's political team wanted boldness. Hammond was sidelined.
historicalPrecedents.lesson: PM-Chancellor misalignment on the dominant political issue paralyses fiscal policy.

historicalPrecedents.dynamic: Initial collaboration during COVID. Broke down over spending restraint. Sunak resigned, precipitating Johnson's fall.
historicalPrecedents.lesson: A Chancellor who publicly positions as fiscally responsible gains personal credibility but creates PM tension.

historicalPrecedents.dynamic: Total alignment on supply-side ideology. No internal checks. Both sacked within weeks.
historicalPrecedents.lesson: PM-Chancellor alignment without external checks (OBR, markets) is catastrophic.

conservatives.state: Worst defeat in party history. Leadership contest pending (July-November 2024).
conservatives._note: Badenoch eventually won. Party deciding between centrist modernisation and right-wing pivot.
conservatives.fiscalPosition: Will attack Labour on both higher taxes and wasteful spending. Hypocritical but effective.
conservatives.threatLevel: Low in near term (2024-25). Medium term depends on leadership direction.

reformUK.threat: Primary threat is pulling Conservatives rightward and fragmenting the right. Could deprive Conservatives of recovery if Reform maintains 10%+ vote share.
reformUK.fiscalPosition: Tax cuts funded by spending cuts on 'waste', net zero cancellation, immigration reduction. Simplistic but populist.

liberalDemocrats.position: Centre. Strong in affluent southern England seats. Attacks from the left on NHS, social care, environment.
liberalDemocrats.fiscalPosition: More willing to advocate tax rises for public services than either major party.

snp.state: Collapsed from 48 seats. Internal turmoil, leadership changes, police investigation.
snp.relevance: Reduced Westminster influence. Devolution and Barnett formula still create fiscal complexity.

theGuardian.attitudeToLabour: Broadly supportive but will criticise from the left

financialTimes.influence: Very high among markets and policymakers
financialTimes.attitudeToLabour: Fair. Will praise or criticise based on policy quality.

bbc._note: Sets the news agenda. Government attacks on BBC bias from both sides are routine.

ifs.name: Institute for Fiscal Studies
ifs.influence: Very high. Post-budget analysis is definitive.

backbenchRevoltMechanics._description: How rebellions work in Parliament and when they matter

symbolic.effect: Media story. No policy impact. Signal of discontent.

significant.effect: Government takes notice. May modify policy. Opposition can amplify.

dangerous.effect: Government may lose vote if opposition unites. Major political crisis.

defeatingMajority.effect: Government loses the vote (needs 88+ rebels if all opposition votes against). Leadership crisis.

rebellionThresholds._note: With a 174-seat majority, it takes 88 Labour MPs voting against to defeat the government. This is a very high bar.

whippingSystem.threeLineWhip: Must attend and vote with government. Breaking = serious consequences.
whippingSystem.twoLineWhip: Must attend. Abstention acceptable in some circumstances.
whippingSystem.freeVote: No party instruction. Rare on fiscal matters.
consequences: In extreme cases: removal of whip (expulsion from parliamentary party)

historicalRevoltExamples.outcome: Government won but with opposition support. Massive political damage.
historicalRevoltExamples.lesson: Even huge rebellions may not defeat government if opposition is divided.

historicalRevoltExamples.outcome: Government defeated. Blair's first Commons defeat.
historicalRevoltExamples.lesson: Civil liberties issues can unite unusual coalitions.
Foreign policy rebellions are relatively common.

historicalRevoltExamples.outcome: Rebels expelled from party. Government lost majority.

plpMechanics._description: Parliamentary Labour Party has its own internal mechanisms
plpMechanics.plpMeetings: Weekly when Parliament sits. PM, Chancellor attend. Can be stormy.
plpMechanics.confidenceVote: PLP can pass a motion of no confidence in the leader. Requires 20% of PLP to trigger (currently ~82 MPs). Not binding but politically devastating if lost.
plpMechanics.nec: National Executive Committee can intervene on party policy and discipline.

interestGroupReactions._description: How key interest groups react to different fiscal policies

cbi.name: Confederation of British Industry
cbi.reactionToCorpTaxRise: Strongly negative. Will warn of investment flight.
cbi.reactionToNhsFunding: Neutral to positive (healthy workforce benefits business)
cbi.influence: Medium. Damaged by sexual harassment scandal (2023) but recovering.

bma.name: British Medical Association
bma.keyDemand: Pay restoration (junior doctors claimed 35% real-terms cut since 2008)
bma.reactionToNhsCuts: Extremely vocal. Will pursue industrial action.

rcn.name: Royal College of Nursing
rcn.reactionToPayFreeze: Unprecedented willingness to strike demonstrated in 2022-23
rcn.influence: Very high. Nurses have highest public trust of any profession.

tuc.name: Trades Union Congress
tuc.influenceOnLabour: Significant via funding and conference votes. Less direct policy control than historically.

approvalRatingModel._note: New government honeymoon. Typically declines 5-10 points in first year.
approvalRatingModel._unit: Points per month natural decay in first year, slowing over time
approvalRatingModel._interpretation: Negative events are weighted 2x vs positive events in approval calculations (behavioural economics)
approvalRatingModel._unit: Days. How quickly a single news story fades.

cumulativeEffects._note: Unlike individual events which decay, cumulative service quality changes (NHS waiting lists, crime, potholes) compound and become permanent drags on approval.

backbenchSatisfaction._note: Below 40, backbench rebellions become likely on any contentious vote.
